Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Feasibility Study for a Wide-Area WiMAX Infrastructure for Wireless Experimentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is evaluating the feasibility of an outdoor wireless experimentation facility that leverages WiMAX base stations and clients. WiMAX has been one of the candidate standards for 4G cellular networks, and is technologically fairly similar to the more popular 4G standards, namely LTE. The experimentation facility, if successful, will allow researchers (both local to the University of Wisconsin-Madison and external) to deploy new types of wireless services on them and experiment with them in a realistic manner. However, building such an experimental facility is a significant challenge due to various issues related to design, operations, maintainability, and usability. The goal of this project is to evaluate the feasibility and define one possible way to implement such an experimental infrastructure in the future.

To create a preliminary prototype to evaluate feasibility, the researchers at UW-Madison are deploying a small number of commercial-grade wireless base stations at various outdoor locations in and around the university campus and beyond. The researchers are also deploying different client devices to test the functioning of the infrastructure to evaluate various strategies of acquiring users in the system. Furthermore, the project is also setting up appropriate network connectivity that can in the future provide suitable isolation between some of the more critical functions and the more experimental ones on the infrastructure. The project is being realized through an academia-industry partnership in the Madison area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project has been to evaluate the feasibility of a wide-area wireless network dedicated to experimentation with diverse wireless systems. To ensure that the infrastructure is useful in a practical setting, the infrastructure was intended to cover a large urban downtown area -- in Madison, Wisconsin -- and through it understand the challenges of setting up similar testbeds at even large scales to support future research endeavors.

 

Through this project, the team was successful in meeting the above goals. Specifically, the team accomplished the following goals:

1. Setup a network consisting multiple WiMAX base stations, and enabled them to support experimentation in wireless systems. These base stations were made available to the project, at no cost, by a local partner. Each base station was configured to allow flow-level control of traffic right at the network’s edge. The sites are being picked based on roof-top access across different vantage points. A key aspect of the deployment is to complete the various cabling and network connectivity issues for this infrastructure. Experimental FCC spectrum licenses for these sites were leveraged for this project.

2. The team also deployed a number of WiMAX clients in the wide area, spanning both static and mobile users. 

3. The team explored an integration path that allows co-existence between experimental activities and services that required high reliability.

4. To demonstrate the usefulness of this platform, the team deployed an end-to-end experiment to analyze transit behavior in a public transit system in the local area, using wireless-based analytics, and worked wit

h the local transit operator to validate its efficacy.
